Recall the rules:
– Good relationships are transitive. (If A is good with B and B is good with C then A is good with C.)
– If person A has a bad relationship with B and is good with C, then B and C must be bad with each other.
– A “group” is a set where every pair has a good relationship (directly or by transitivity). Moreover, if someone in one group is bad with someone in another, then all cross-group pairs are bad.

Step 1. Identify the groups from the good relationships.

• From (3), (8), and (9): C is good with A, F, and E. This groups {A, C, E, F}.

These groupings look natural. Next, we check the bad relationship statements to ensure no conflict within a group:

• Statement (12) says C and H have a bad relationship. C is in {A, C, E, F} while H is in {B, D, G, H} – so they are in different groups.
• Statement (2) (F and J), (4) (E and J), (5) (E and G), and (10) (G and J) involve members from different groups.

Within each group everyone is in a good relationship with everyone else (by definition and transitivity). Also, because there is at least one bad relationship between one person in a group and one in another, rule 5 forces every pair from two different groups to have a bad relationship.

Bad pairs (pairs from different groups):
